question: Suppose $X_1, ..., X_n$ are independent samples from an unknown distribution with finite mean and variance. Which of the following statements about $\hat{\sigma}^2$ is incorrect?

answers.answer: $\hat{\sigma}^2$ measures the spread of the sample around the sample mean.
answers.feedback: This is true. The sample variance quantifies the spread of the data around the sample mean.
This is true. The sample variance calculation explicitly uses $\hat{\mu}$, so it depends on the sample mean.

answers.answer: $\hat{\sigma}^2$ can take on negative values if the sample values are small.
answers.feedback: Correct! This is false, since variances are always non-negative, as they are calculated by summing squared deviations.

answers.answer: $\hat{\sigma}^2$ is computed using all the sample data points.
answers.feedback: This is true. Every sample data point $X_i$ is included in the computation of $\hat{\sigma}^2$.
